prior_works.title: Data re-uploading for a universal quantum classifier
prior_works.authors: Adrián Pérez-Salinas, Alba Cervera-Lierta, Elies Gil-Fuster, José I. Latorre
prior_works.role: Introduced data re-uploading architectures and proved universality of PQCs via repeated data encodings.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The present paper builds on data re-uploading as the core architectural motif and moves beyond this universality result by giving explicit constructions and non-asymptotic error bounds for approximating multivariate polynomials and smooth functions.

prior_works.title: The effect of data encoding on the expressive power of variational quantum machine learning models
prior_works.authors: Maria Schuld, Ryan Sweke, Johannes Jakob Meyer
prior_works.role: Characterized expectation values of encoded PQCs as finite Fourier series with frequency sets determined by encoding gates and repetitions.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This Fourier-analytic characterization underpins the paper’s constructive designs and enables translating the number of re-uploadings and circuit depth into attainable polynomial degree and, hence, explicit approximation error rates.

prior_works.title: Quantum Circuit Learning
prior_works.authors: Kentarō Mitarai, Makoto Negoro, Masahiro Kitagawa, Keisuke Fujii
prior_works.role: Showed that PQC expectation values can represent polynomial/trigonometric features of inputs and proposed fitting classical functions with PQCs.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The new work formalizes and systematizes this early link between PQCs and polynomial approximation by giving precise, non-asymptotic error bounds for multivariate polynomials and smooth functions and by quantifying the required circuit resources.

prior_works.title: The power of data in quantum machine learning
prior_works.authors: Amira Abbas, David Sutter, Christoph Zoufal, Aurélien Lucchi, Alessio Figalli, Stefan Woerner
prior_works.role: Analyzed expressivity and trainability of PQCs through data encoding, showing how repeated encodings expand the accessible frequency spectrum.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: These insights directly motivate the paper’s use of re-uploading to control frequency content, which is then converted into rigorous non-asymptotic approximation error bounds.

prior_works.title: Quantum singular value transformation and quantum signal processing
prior_works.authors: András Gilyén, Yuan Su, Guang Hao Low, Nathan Wiebe
prior_works.role: Provided constructive methods to implement bounded-degree polynomials of trigonometric functions via sequences of single-qubit rotations, with tight degree–depth relations.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The constructive polynomial-implementation paradigm informs how the paper maps target polynomial degree to PQC depth/parameters, enabling explicit resource–error tradeoffs.

prior_works.title: Constructive Approximation
prior_works.authors: Ronald A. DeVore, George G. Lorentz
prior_works.role: Classical approximation theory establishing non-asymptotic error rates for approximating smooth multivariate functions by polynomials/trigonometric polynomials.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper leverages these classical degree–error rates and couples them with PQC Fourier/polynomial realizability to derive resource-dependent, non-asymptotic bounds for PQC approximation of smooth functions.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—explicit constructions of data re-uploading PQCs with the first non-asymptotic approximation error bounds for multivariate polynomials and smooth functions—emerges from combining three threads of prior work. First, foundational results on data re-uploading universality (Pérez-Salinas et al.) established that repeated data encodings can render PQCs universal, while early demonstrations that PQCs generate polynomial/trigonometric features (Mitarai et al.) suggested a natural pathway to approximating classical functions. Second, harmonic analyses of data encoding (Schuld et al.; Abbas et al.) rigorously characterized the output of such circuits as finite Fourier series with frequency content governed by the number and structure of re-uploadings. These results provide the precise mechanism by which circuit depth and repetitions control the representable polynomial degree, which is essential for moving from existential universality to quantitative approximation guarantees. Third, constructive tools for realizing polynomials in quantum circuits (Gilyén et al., via quantum signal processing/singular value transformation) supply degree–depth relations that align with the Fourier-based picture, while classical constructive approximation theory (DeVore & Lorentz) delivers non-asymptotic degree–error rates for multivariate polynomials and smooth function classes. By fusing these ingredients, the paper translates desired approximation accuracy into explicit bounds on qubits, depth, and trainable parameters for data re-uploading PQCs, resolving the gap between nonconstructive universality claims and practical, resource-aware expressivity guarantees.
